source_scope.notes: Past 12 hours; avoids fear-based crime coverage.

articles.title: A few flakes possible tonight as colder air settles into the Quincy area
summary: Friday is cooler and breezy, with northwest winds and highs mainly in the mid-40s.
Showers return tonight as temperatures near freezing, so some rain may mix with snow showers; accumulation is expected to be limited (generally a dusting).
Colder weekend conditions follow (upper 30s Saturday, 30s Sunday) before a warmer start to next week.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
A cooler air mass moved into the Tri-States, keeping Quincy breezy with northwest winds and lower daytime highs compared with earlier in the week. Tonight’s precipitation chances increase, and as temperatures drop toward freezing, some of the showers may transition into snow showers.

## Why it matters
Even light snow can create slick spots on bridges, ramps, and untreated side streets—especially overnight into the early morning when surface temps are lowest.

## What to watch
Watch for brief bursts of snow mixing in late tonight, then colder highs over the weekend. If you’ll be driving early Saturday, check road conditions for any patchy slick areas.

articles.title: If your vehicle stalls on railroad tracks, the safest move is to exit immediately and use the crossing ID sign
summary: Operation Lifesaver reports roughly 2,250 train–motor vehicle collisions occurred in 2024, underscoring why crossings should never be treated casually.
If a car stalls on tracks: get everyone out, move away from the tracks, locate the blue-and-white crossing sign, and call the number to report the crossing’s unique ID.
The same number should be used to report unsafe issues like malfunctioning warning devices or visibility obstructions at crossings.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
A railroad-safety reminder circulated for the Quincy area emphasizing what to do if a vehicle becomes stuck or stalled on a rail crossing.

## Why it matters
Trains require long distances to stop, and crossing incidents escalate fast—especially if drivers try to push a vehicle off the tracks or ignore warning devices.

## What to watch
Make sure everyone in your household knows the “blue sign” step: exit the vehicle, move away, and use the crossing sign’s phone number and ID so rail dispatch can be alerted quickly.

articles.title: Quincy University opens new Occupational and Physical Therapy doctoral facility to expand regional healthcare training
summary: Quincy University marked the opening of a new facility supporting Occupational Therapy (OTD) and Physical Therapy (DPT) doctoral programs with a ribbon cutting and open house at its North Campus (17th & Seminary Road).
The programs are described as hybrid, combining online coursework with in-person lab experiences for skills, simulation, and collaborative learning.
The OT doctoral cohort began coursework on January 5, and the PT doctoral program is slated to start in August.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
Quincy University opened a new doctoral training facility for occupational and physical therapy programs, celebrating the milestone with a ribbon cutting and open house at its North Campus.

## Why it matters
OT and PT are high-demand healthcare roles, and expanding local training capacity can help address regional workforce needs while keeping students and talent in the area.

## What to watch
Watch for enrollment updates and the August launch timeline for the DPT program, plus any new clinical partnership announcements tied to the programs’ hands-on training components.

articles.title: Adams County reports 47 new business openings in 2025 as local groups push startup resources
summary: Local development groups report Adams County saw 47 new businesses open in 2025; after closures, the net gain is reported at around 30.
A featured example is “What’s the Niche?” at 522 S. 8th Street in Quincy, highlighting vendor-based retail and event-style offerings (like painting parties).
GREDF, the Quincy Area Chamber, and The District created a Business Start-Up Guide aimed at making the process of opening a business more navigable with contacts and step-by-step resources.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
A local report highlighted an increase in new business activity across Adams County, pointing to dozens of openings during 2025 and ongoing efforts to support entrepreneurs.

## Why it matters
New business formation is a practical indicator of local confidence and can broaden services, jobs, and foot traffic—especially when paired with support tools that reduce friction for first-time owners.

## What to watch
Watch whether the startup guide increases follow-through (permits, financing, and storefront stability) and whether net gains remain positive as 2026 progresses.

articles.title: Adams County real estate snapshot: late December sales include multiple Quincy home transfers and several higher-value acreage deals
summary: A compiled set of property transfers (sourced from Illinois Real Estate Transfer Declaration forms) provides a week-style snapshot of recorded transactions across Adams County.
Examples include Quincy residential transfers spanning a wide price range (including lower-cost and mid-market sales) plus several larger acreage transactions outside the city.
The publication notes that listed dates may differ from actual transaction or recording dates, and additional details can be obtained from recorded documents.
articles.body_markdown:
## What happened
A local real estate roundup listed recorded transfers in Adams County covering late December through early January, including multiple Quincy addresses and several rural/acreage deals.

## Why it matters
These records help residents and local businesses track market activity (pricing ranges, turnover, and where transactions are clustering) without relying on anecdote.

## What to watch
Watch whether higher-value acreage deals continue into mid-winter (often a slower season) and whether Quincy’s mid-market inventory remains tight or loosens as spring approaches.
